variable: GDP (current US$ billions)
text_title: Index team calculations based on World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using single year official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.

variable: Population
text_title: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), World Population Prospects 2019
text_source: Total Population - Both Sexes. De facto population in a country, area or region as of 1 July of the year indicated. Projections based on medium fertility variant.

variable: Human Development Index (HDI)
text_title: United Nations Development Programme, Human Development Data
text_source: The HDI was created to emphasize that people and their capabilities should be the ultimate criteria for assessing the development of a country, not economic growth alone. The HDI is a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, being knowledgeable and have a decent standard of living. The HDI is the geometric mean of normalized indices for each of the three dimensions. The health dimension is assessed by life expectancy at birth, the education dimension is measured by mean of years of schooling for adults aged 25 years and more and expected years of schooling for children of school entering age. The standard of living dimension is measured by gross national income per capita. The HDI uses the logarithm of income, to reflect the diminishing importance of income with increasing GNI. The scores for the three HDI dimension indices are then aggregated into a composite index using geometric mean.

variable: Gross enrolment ratio, primary, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of students enrolled in primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the official school-age population corresponding to the same level of education. Enrolment count should include all types of schools and education institutions, including public, private and all other institutions that provide organized educational programmes.

variable: Gross enrolment ratio, upper secondary, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of students enrolled in upper secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the official school-age population corresponding to the same level of education.

variable: Rate of out-of-school children and adolescents of primary and lower secondary school age, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Children in the official primary and lower secondary school age range who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary schools.

variable: Gross graduation ratio from primary education, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of graduates, regardless of age, in primary education, expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age for this level or programme.

variable: Gross graduation ratio from upper secondary education, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of graduates, regardless of age in upper secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age for this level or programme.

variable: Survival rate to the last grade of lower secondary general education, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Percentage of a cohort of students enrolled in the first grade of a given level or cycle of education in a given school year who are expected to reach a given grade, regardless of repetition. Survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years. Rates approaching 100% indicate a high level of retention and low incidence of dropout.

variable: Assessment of 15-year-old students in mathematics, science and reading
text_title: Index team calculations based on Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), Program for International Student Assessment (PISA)
text_source: The OECD Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) assesses the extent to which 15-year-old students near the end of their compulsory education have acquired key knowledge and skills that are essential for full participation in modern societies. The assessment focuses on the core school subjects of science
column6: in addition to students’ proficiency in an innovative domain (in 2015
column7: this was collaborative problem solving). PISA does not just ascertain whether students can reproduce knowledge; it also examines how well students can extrapolate knowledge from what they have learned and apply it in unfamiliar settings
column8: both in and outside of school. The scores are calculated in each year so that the mean is 500 and the standard deviation 100. This variable is calculated by the GKI team by taking the average of the mean score of 15-year-old students in mathematics literacy

variable: Assessment of 8th grade achievement in mathematics and science
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA), Lynch School of Education, Boston College, and TIMSS and PIRLS International Study Center, TIMSS 2015/2011/2007 International Results Reports
text_source: The mathematics and science achievement results are reported as average scores and distributions on the grade 8 mathematics and science achievement scales. Each scale summarizes students’ performance on a large number of test items designed to measure the breadth of science content, as well as a range of cognitive processes within the knowing, applying and reasoning domains. This variable is calculated by the GKI team by taking the average of the 8th grade achievement in mathematics and in science.

variable: Government expenditure on primary education as a percentage of GDP (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source:
Total general (local, regional and central) government expenditure on primary education (current, capital and transfers), expressed as a percentage of GDP. This includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government. The variable is reported as a three-year average.
Pre-University Education,Government expenditure on secondary education as a percentage of GDP (%)"
text_body: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
column6: Total general (local, regional and central) government expenditure on secondary education (current, capital and transfers), expressed as a percentage of GDP. This includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government.  The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: Current expenditure as a percentage of total expenditure in public institutions (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Current expenditure expressed as a percentage of direct expenditure in public educational institutions (instructional and non-instructional). Financial aid to students and other transfers are excluded from direct expenditure. Current expenditure is consumed within the current year and would need to be renewed if required in the following year. This includes staff compensation and current expenditure other than for staff compensation (e.g. for teaching materials, ancillary services and administration).

variable: Gross enrolment ratio, early childhood education, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of students enrolled in early childhood education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the official school-age population corresponding to this level of education.

variable: Percentage of new entrants to grade 1 of primary education with early childhood education experience, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Total number of new entrants to Grade 1 of primary education who have attended some form of organized early childhood care and education programmes, expressed as a percentage of the total number of new entrants to primary education.

variable: Pupil-teacher ratio in primary education (headcount basis)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Average number of pupils per teacher in primary education, based on headcounts of both pupils and teachers.

variable: Pupil-teacher ratio in secondary education (headcount basis)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Average number of pupils per teacher in secondary education, based on headcounts of both pupils and teachers.

variable: Percentage of teachers in primary education who are trained, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Percentage of teachers in primary education who have received at least the minimum organized pre-service and in-service pedagogical teacher training required for teaching at the relevant level in a given country.

variable: Percentage of teachers in secondary education who are trained, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Percentage of teachers in secondary education who have received at least the minimum organized pre-service and in-service pedagogical teacher training required for teaching at the relevant level in a given country.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Extent of staff training
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do companies invest in training and employee development? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Availability of research and training services
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how available are high-quality, professional training services? [1 = not available at all; 7 = widely available].

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Percent of firms offering formal training
text_title: World Bank, Enterprise Surveys
text_source: Percentage of firms offering formal training programs for their permanent, full-time employees. This indicator is computed using data from manufacturing firms only.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Expenditure on secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary vocational education as a percentage of total government expenditure (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Total general (local, regional and central) government expenditure on education (current, capital, and transfers), expressed as a percentage of total general government expenditure on all sectors (including health, education, social services, etc.). It includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government. The variable is reported as a three-year average. Vocational education is designed for learners to acquire the knowledge, skills and competencies specific to a particular occupation or trade, or class of occupations or trades. Vocational education may have work-based components (e.g. apprenticeships). The successful completion of such programmes leads to labour-market-relevant vocational qualifications becoming acknowledged as occupationally-oriented by the relevant national authorities and/or the labour market.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Share of all students in secondary education enrolled in vocational programmes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Total number of students enrolled in vocational programmes in secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students enrolled in all programmes (vocational and general) at that level. Enrolment count should include all types of schools and education institutions, including public, private and all other institutions that provide organized educational programmes.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Share of all students in post-secondary non-tertiary education enrolled in vocational programmes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Total number of students enrolled in vocational programmes in post-secondary, non-tertiary education, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students enrolled in all programmes (vocational and general) at that level.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Pupil-teacher ratio in secondary vocational education (headcount basis)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Average number of pupils enrolled per teacher in secondary vocational education, based on headcounts of both pupils and teachers.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Poor work ethic in national labour force
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: This variable is determined by the responses of business executives who were asked to select the five most problematic factors out of 16 options for doing business in their economy and rank them from 1 (most problematic) to 5. The 16 factors were: corruption access to financing
column15: poor work ethic in national labour force
column17: tax rates and tax regulations. The results were weighted according to the ranking assigned by respondents."

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Ease of finding skilled employees  World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_title: Based on the survey question: In your country, how easy is it for companies to find employees with the required skills for their business needs? [1 = extremely difficult, 7 = extremely easy].

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Technicians per thousand labour force (HC)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of persons whose main tasks require technical knowledge and experience in one or more fields of engineering, the physical and life sciences, or the social sciences, humanities and the arts (who participate in R&D by performing scientific and technical tasks involving the application of concepts, operational methods and the use of research equipment, normally under the supervision of researchers) during a given year expressed as a proportion of a labour force of 1,000 people. The labour force comprises all persons of working age who furnish the supply of labour for the production of goods and services during a specified time-reference period. It refers to the sum of all persons of working age who are employed and those who are unemployed. (UIS reference data for labour force are from ILO, thus the definition is from ILO).

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Restrictive labour regulations
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: This variable is determined from the responses of business executives who were asked to select the five most problematic factors out of 16 options for doing business in their economy and rank them from 1 (most problematic) to 5. The 16 factors were: corruption access to financing, crime and theft, foreign currency regulations, government instability/coups, inadequate supply of infrastructure, inadequately educated workforce, inefficient government bureaucracy, inflation, insufficient capacity to innovate, policy instability, poor public health, poor work ethic in national labour force, restrictive labour regulations, tax rates and tax regulations. The results were weighted according to the ranking assigned by respondents.

category: Technical and Vocational Education and Training
variable: Labour freedom
text_title: The Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom dataset
text_source: Labour freedom is a component of the regulatory efficiency category of the economic freedom index that quantitatively measures various aspects of the legal and regulatory framework of a country’s labour market, including regulations concerning minimum wages, laws inhibiting layoffs, severance requirements, and measurable regulatory restraints on hiring and hours worked, plus the labour force participation rate as an indicative measure of employment opportunities in the labour market. Seven quantitative sub-factors are equally weighted, with each counted as one-seventh of the labour freedom component.

variable: Government expenditure on tertiary education as a percentage of GDP (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Total general (local, regional and central) government expenditure on secondary education (current, capital, and transfers), expressed as a percentage of GDP. This includes expenditure funded by transfers from international sources to government.  The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: Government expenditure per tertiary student (constant PPP$)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Average total (current, capital and transfers) general government expenditure per student in tertiary education, expressed in purchasing power parity (PPP) dollars at constant prices. The constant prices base year is normally three years before the year of the data release. This variable was calculated by dividing government expenditure on tertiary education in constant PPP$ (millions) by the number of students enrolled in all tertiary education programmes.

variable: Share of all students in tertiary education enrolled in ISCED 6 (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 6 as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education. Enrolment count should include all types of schools and education institutions, including public, private and all other institutions that provide organised educational programmes. Programmes at ISCED level 6 - Bachelor’s or equivalent level - are often designed to provide participants with intermediate academic and/or professional knowledge, skills and competencies, leading to a first degree or equivalent qualification. Programmes at this level are typically theoretically-based but may include practical components and are informed by state-of-the-art research and/or best professional practice. They are traditionally offered by universities and equivalent tertiary educational institutions.

variable: Share of all students in tertiary education enrolled in ISCED 7 (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 7 as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education. Programmes at ISCED level 7 - Master’s or equivalent level - are often designed to provide participants with advanced academic and/or professional knowledge, skills and competencies, leading to a second degree or equivalent qualification. Programmes at this level may have a substantial research component but do not yet lead to the award of a doctoral qualification. Typically, programmes at this level are theory-based but may include practical components and are informed by state-of-the-art research and/or best professional practice. They are traditionally offered by universities and other tertiary educational institutions.

variable: Share of all students in tertiary education enrolled in ISCED 8 (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 8 as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education.  Programmes at ISCED level 8 - doctoral or equivalent level - are designed primarily to lead to an advanced research qualification. Programmes at this ISCED level are devoted to advanced study and original research and are typically offered only by research-oriented tertiary educational institutions such as universities. Doctoral programmes exist in both academic and professional fields.

variable: Pupil-teacher ratio in tertiary education (headcount basis)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Average number of pupils enrolled per teacher at a given level of education (in this case tertiary), based on headcounts of pupils and teachers.

variable: Researchers (HC) - Higher education (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Researchers in Higher Education are professionals engaged in the conception or creation of new knowledge (who conduct research and improve or develop concepts, theories, models, techniques instrumentation, software or operational methods) employed in the Higher Education sector. The higher education sector comprises, all universities, colleges of technology and other institutions providing formal tertiary education programmes (i.e. ISCED levels 5, 6, 7, or 8), whatever their source of finance or legal status and all research institutes, centres, experimental stations and clinics that have their R&D activities under the direct control of, or are administered by, tertiary education institutions.

variable: Percentage of graduates from ISCED 6 programmes, both sexes (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: This variable was computed by dividing graduates from ISCED 6 programmes in tertiary education by the number of graduates from tertiary education, both sexes.

variable: Percentage of graduates from ISCED 7 programmes, both sexes (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: This variable was computed by dividing graduates from ISCED 7 programmes in tertiary education by the number of graduates from tertiary education, both sexes.

variable: Percentage of graduates from ISCED 8 programmes, both sexes (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: This variable was calculated by dividing graduates from ISCED 8 programmes in tertiary education by the number of graduates from tertiary education, both sexes.

variable: Labour force with advanced education, both sexes (% of total labour force) (15+)
text_title: International Labour Organisation (ILO), ILOSTAT Database
text_source: The labour force comprises all persons of working age who furnish the supply of labour for the production of goods and services during a specified time-reference period. It refers to the sum of all persons of working age who are employed and those who are unemployed; while advanced education comprises short-cycle tertiary education, a bachelor’s degree or equivalent education level, a master’s degree or equivalent education level, or doctoral degree or equivalent education level according to the International Standard Classification of Education 2011 (ISCED 2011).

variable: Unemployment rate with advanced education (% of total labour force with advanced education) (15+)
text_title: International Labour Organization (ILO), ILOSTAT
text_source: The percentage of the labour force with an advanced level of education who are unemployed.

variable: University-industry collaboration in R&D
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do business and universities collaborate on research and development (R&D)? [1 = do not collaborate at all; 7 = collaborate extensively].

variable: Globally-ranked universities (points)
text_title: Social Progress Imperative, Social Progress Index database based on Times Higher Education World University Rankings, QS World University Rankings, and Academic Ranking of World Universities
text_source: The number of universities ranked on any of the three most widely used international university rankings, converted to a point-scale with universities in the top 400 on any list are given double weight. The indicator is log-transformed in calculation.

variable: Percent of tertiary students enrolled in globally-ranked universities
text_title: Social Progress Imperative, Social Progress Index database based on UNESCO; Times Higher Education World University Rankings, QS World University Rankings, and Academic Ranking of World Universities
text_source: The enrolment at globally ranked universities as a percentage of the total number of tertiary students.

variable: Inbound mobility rate, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Number of students from abroad studying in a given country, expressed as a percentage of total tertiary enrolment in that country.

variable: GERD as a percentage of GDP (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Gross domestic expenditure on R&D (GERD) as a percentage of GDP is the total intramural expenditure on R&D performed in the national territory during a specific reference period expressed as a percentage of GDP of the national territory. The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: GERD per researcher, HC (in '000 PPP$, constant prices - 2005)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: GERD per researcher is the total intramural expenditure on R&D performed during a specific reference period per researcher, expressed in Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) that is a currency exchange rate that equalize the purchasing power of different currencies. The headcount (HC) of R&D personnel is defined as the total number of individuals contributing to intramural R&D, at the level of a statistical unit or at an aggregate level, during a specific reference period (usually a calendar year). That means headcount data reflect the total number of persons who are mainly or partially employed in R&D. The use of HCs is mostly recommended in terms of exploring, usually in percentage terms, the characteristics of R&D personnel.

variable: Researchers per thousand labour force (HC)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Researchers per thousand labour force refers to the number of professionals engaged in the conception or creation of new knowledge (who conduct research and improve or develop concepts, theories, models, techniques instrumentation, software or operational methods) during a given year expressed as a proportion of a labour force of 1,000 people. The labour force comprises all persons of working age who furnish the supply of labour for the production of goods and services during a specified time-reference period. It refers to the sum of all persons of working age who are employed and those who are unemployed. (UIS reference data for labour force are from ILO, thus the definition is from ILO).

variable: Percentage of graduates from science, technology, engineering and mathematics programmes in tertiary education, both sexes (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: The percentage of students who have successfully graduated from tertiary education in information and communication technologies, natural sciences, mathematics and statistics or engineering, manufacturing and construction programmes.

variable: High-technology net imports (% of total trade)
text_title: Index team calculations based on United Nations Comtrade, International Trade Statistics Database and on IMF, Balance of Payments and International Investment Position Statistics
text_source: High-technology imports minus re-imports expressed as a percentage of total trade. The list of commodities contains technical products with a high intensity of R&D, based on the Eurostat classification, itself based on SITC Rev.4 and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) definition. Commodities belong to the following sectors: aerospace; computers and office machines; electronics, telecommunications; pharmacy; scientific instruments; electrical machinery; chemistry; non- electrical machinery; and armaments. Total trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services excluding trade in government goods and services divided by 2.

variable: Average documents per researcher
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database and Scimago Journal, Scimago Journal & Country Rank
text_source: Average published documents in the period 1996–2006 per researcher (HC). Headcount data reflects the total number of persons who are mainly or partially employed in R&D.

variable: Citations per document
text_title: Scimago Journal, Scimago Journal and Country Rank
text_source: Average number of citations of documents published during 1996–2016.

variable: Citable documents H index
text_title: Scimago Journal, Scimago Journal and Country Rank
text_source: Country's number of articles (h) that have received at least h citations.

variable: SJR ranking of the best scientific journal in the country
text_title: Scimago Journal, Scimago Journal and Country Rank
text_source: Scimago Journal Rank indicator is a measure of a journal's impact, influence or prestige. It expresses the average number of weighted citations received in the selected year by the documents published in the best journal in the country in the three previous years.

variable: Quality of research institutions
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how do you assess the quality of scientific research institutions? [1 = extremely poor—among the worst in the world; 7 = extremely good—among the best in the world].

variable: Patent applications/million population
text_title: World Economic Forum, The Global Competitiveness Index 2007-2017 and 4.0 2018 and 2019 datasets based on OECD, Patent Database and IMF, World Economic Outlook Database
text_source: This variable measures the total count of applications filed under the Patent Cooperation Treaty (PCT), by priority date and inventor nationality, using fractional count if an application is filed by multiple inventors. The average count of applications filed in 2012 and 2013 is divided by population, using figures from the World Bank’s World Development Indicators.

variable: GERD performed by business enterprises as a percentage of GDP (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: GERD performed by business enterprises as a percentage of GDP is the total intramural expenditure on R&D performed during a specific reference period corresponding to business enterprise, independent of the source of funds, as a percentage of GDP. In the context of R&D statistics, the business enterprise sector comprises all resident corporations, including legally incorporated enterprises, regardless of the residence of their shareholders. This group includes all other types of quasi-corporations, i.e. units capable of generating a profit or other financial gain for their owners, recognized by law as separate legal entities from their owners, and set up for the purposes of engaging in market production at prices that are economically significant. The unincorporated branches of non-resident enterprises are deemed to be resident because they are engaged in production on the economic territory on a long-term basis and all resident non-profit institutions (NPIs) that are market producers of goods or services or serve business. This sector comprises both private and public enterprises. The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: GERD - financed by business enterprises (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: GERD financed by business enterprise is the total intramural expenditure on R&D performed during a specific reference period financed by business enterprise as a percentage of total gross expenditure on R&D.

variable: Researchers (HC) - Business enterprise (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Researchers by sector of employment: professionals engaged in the conception or creation of new knowledge (who conduct research and improve or develop concepts, theories, models, techniques instrumentation, software or operational methods) broken down by the sectors they are employed in (business enterprise, government, higher education and private non-profit organisations). See variable 4.12 for the definition of business enterprise sector in RDI.

variable: Foreign direct investment (FDI) and technology transfer
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: To what extent does foreign direct investment (FDI) bring new technology into your country? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

variable: Intellectual property receipts, % of total trade
text_title: Index team calculations based on IMF, Balance of Payments and International Investment Position Statistics
text_source: Charges for the use of intellectual property not included elsewhere receipts (% of total trade) according to the Extended Balance of Payments Services Classification EBOPS 2010. Receipts are between residents and non-residents for the use of proprietary rights (such as patents, trade-marks, copyrights, industrial processes, and designs including trade secrets, franchises), and for licenses to reproduce or distribute (or both) intellectual property embodied in produced originals or prototypes (such as copyrights on books and manuscripts, computer software, cinematographic works, and sound recordings) and related rights (such as for live performances and television, cable, or satellite broadcast).

variable: Number of designs contained in industrial design applications filed at a given national or regional office (per billion PPP$ GDP)
text_title: Index team calculations based on WIPO, Intellectual Property Statistics and IMF, World Economic Outlook Database
text_source: Refers to the number of designs contained in industrial design applications filed at a given national or regional office. Data refer to industrial design application design counts – the number of designs contained in applications – and include designs contained in resident industrial design applications filed at both the national office and the regional office, where applicable. Resident design counts refers to the number of designs contained in applications filed with the IP office of – or at an office acting on behalf of – the state or jurisdiction in which the applicant has residence. For example, an application filed with the Japan Patent Office (JPO) by a resident of Japan is considered a resident application for Japan. Similarly, an application filed with the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) by an applicant who resides in any of the OHIM member states, such as Italy, is considered as a resident application for that member state (Italy).

variable: Production process sophistication
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how sophisticated are production processes? [1 = not at all—production uses labour-intensive processes; 7 = highly—production uses latest technologies].

variable: Extent of marketing
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how successful are companies in using marketing to differentiate their products and services? [1 = not successful at all; 7 = extremely successful].

variable: Ease of protecting minority investors
text_title: World Bank, Doing Business Database
text_source: It measures the protection of minority investors from conflicts of interest through a set of indicators and shareholders’ rights in corporate governance through another. The data come from a questionnaire administered to corporate and securities lawyers and are based on securities regulations, company laws, civil procedure codes and court rules of evidence. The ranking of economies on the strength of minority investor protections is determined by sorting their distance to frontier scores for protecting minority investors. These scores are the simple average of the distance to frontier scores for the extent of conflict of interest regulation index and the extent of shareholder governance index. An economy’s distance to frontier is reflected on a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 represents the lowest performance and 100 represents the frontier.

variable: Joint venture/strategic alliance deals
text_title: Index team calculations based on Cornell University, INSEAD, and WIPO, The Global Innovation Index datasets based on from Thomson Reuters, Thomson One Banker Private Equity, SDC Platinum database and IMF
text_source: The joint ventures/strategic alliances" variable represents the number of deals
text_body: fractional counting (per billion PPP$ GDP). It is from Thomson Reuters data on joint ventures/strategic alliance deals
column7: with details on the country of origin of partner firms
column9: each participating nation of each company in a deal (n countries per deal) receives
column11: a score equivalent to 1/n (with the effect that all country scores add up to the number of deals reported that year). The data are reported per billion PPP$ GDP."

variable: Share of imported ICT goods as a percentage of total goods imported (%)
text_title: UNCTAD, Division on Technology and Logistics, the Information Economy Database, based on UN DESA Statistics Division and UN Comtrade
text_source: The list of ICT goods is defined by the OECD, and was revised in 2010 and then adapted to HS2012. This new list consists of 93 goods defined at the 6-digit level of the 2012 version of the Harmonized System. The list of ICT goods based on HS 2012 is divided into five categories: Computers and peripheral equipment, communication equipment, consumer electronic equipment, electronic components and miscellaneous.

variable: Total computer software spending (% of GDP)
text_title: Index team calculations based on Cornell University, INSEAD, and WIPO, The Global Innovation Index datasets based on HIS Global Insight, Information and Communication Technology Database
text_source: Computer software spending includes the total value of purchased or leased packaged software such as operating systems, database systems, programming tools, utilities and applications. It excludes expenditures for internal software development and outsourced custom software development. The data are a combination of actual figures and estimates. Data are reported as a percentage of GDP.

variable: New business density
text_title: World Bank, Entrepreneurship Survey and Database
text_source: The number of newly registered firms with limited liability per 1,000 working-age people (ages 15-64) per calendar year.

variable: Number of trademark applications issued to residents at a given national or regional office (per billion PPP$ GDP)
text_title: Index team calculations based on WIPO, Intellectual Property Statistics and IMF, World Economic Outlook Database
text_source: The count of trademark applications is based on the total number of goods and services classes specified in resident trademark applications filed at a given national or regional office in 2015. Data refers to trademark application class counts – the number of classes specified in resident trademark applications – and include those filed at both the national office and the regional office, where applicable. Data are scaled by PPP$ GDP (billions). A ‘trademark’ is a sign used by the owner of certain products or provider of certain services to distinguish them from the products or services of other companies. A trademark can consist of words and/or combinations of words, such as slogans, names, logos, figures and images, letters, numbers, sounds and moving images, or a combination thereof. The procedures for registering trademarks are governed by the legislation and procedures of national and regional IP offices. Trademark rights are limited to the jurisdiction of the IP office that registers the trademark. Trademarks can be registered by filing an application at the relevant national or regional office(s) or by filing an international application through the Madrid System. A resident trademark application is one that is filed with an IP office or an office acting on behalf of the state or jurisdiction in which the applicant has residence. For example, an application filed with the Japan Patent Office (JPO) by a resident of Japan is considered a resident application for Japan. Similarly, an application filed with the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) by an applicant who resides in any of the EU member states, such as France, is considered a resident application for that member state (France).

variable: Number of national feature films produced (per million population 15-69 years old)
text_title: Index team calculations based on UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database and UN DESA, World Population Prospects 2019
text_source: A feature film is a film with a running time of 60 minutes or longer. It includes works of fiction, animation and documentaries. It is intended for commercial exhibition in cinemas. Films produced exclusively for television broadcasting, newsreels, commercials, films in video format and films intended for adults (or rated X), are excluded. Feature film production includes three stages: pre-production, production and post-production.  Nationally-produced feature films include 100% nationally-financed feature films and international co-productions. It excludes production of foreign feature films of which nationally-registered producers do not have any ownership. Data are expressed per million population 15–69 years old.

variable: Printing and publishing manufactured output (% of manufactured total output)
text_title: Index team calculations based on United Nations Industrial Development Organization Statistics (UNIDO); INDSTAT 2 2018, ISIC Revision 3
text_source: This variable includes printing, as well as publishing (whether or not connected with printing).  Publishing involves financial, technical, artistic, legal and marketing activities, among others. The breakdown of publishing activities into classes is based on the type of printed matter or recorded media published. This division includes units engaged in the publishing of newspapers, magazines, other periodicals, and books. In general, these units, which are known as publishers, issue copies of works for which they usually possess copyright. Works may be in one or more formats including traditional print form and electronic form. Publishers may publish works originally created by others for which they have obtained the rights and/or works that they have created in-house.  The printing activities print products, such as newspapers, books, periodicals, business forms, greeting cards, and other materials, and perform support activities, such as bookbinding, plate-making services, and data imaging. The support activities included here are an integral part of the printing industry, and a product (a printing plate, a bound book or a computer disk or file) that is an integral part of the printing industry is almost always provided by these operations.

variable: Share of exported ICT goods as a percentage of total goods exported (%)
text_title: UNCTAD, Division on Technology and Logistics, the Information Economy Database, based on UN DESA Statistics Division and UN Comtrade
text_source: See Share of imported ICT goods as percentage of total goods imported (%)" for more details (variable 4.22)."

variable: Percentage of the population covered by a mobile-cellular network
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: This variable refers to the percentage of inhabitants within range of a mobile-cellular signal, irrespective of whether or not they are subscribers or users. This is calculated by dividing the number of inhabitants within range of a mobile-cellular signal by the total population and multiplying by 100.

variable: International Internet bandwidth per Internet user (Kbit/s)
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: International Internet bandwidth refers to the total used capacity of international Internet bandwidth measured as the sum of the used capacity of all Internet exchanges (locations where Internet traffic is exchanged) offering international bandwidth. If capacity is asymmetric (i.e. with more incoming [downlink] than outgoing [uplink] capacity); then the incoming (downlink) capacity should be provided in (Kbit/s) per Internet user.

variable: Secure Internet servers (per 1 million people)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators based on Netcraft and World Bank population estimates
text_source: Secure servers are servers using encryption technology in Internet transactions. The number of secure Internet servers, from the Netcraft Secure Server Survey, indicates how many companies conduct encrypted transactions over the Internet. The survey examines the use of encrypted transactions through extensive automated exploration, tallying the number of websites using a secure socket layer (SSL). Data are divided by the mid-year population and multiplied by one million. The Internet provides access to the worldwide network. Broadband refers to technologies that provide Internet speeds of at least 256 (Kbit/s) a second of upstream and downstream capacity and includes digital subscriber lines, cable modems, satellite broadband Internet, fiber-to-home Internet access, Ethernet local access networks and wireless area networks.

variable: ICT Price Basket
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), Measuring the Information Society Reports
text_source: The ICT Price Basket (IPB) is a composite basket that includes three price sets, referred to as sub-baskets: the fixed-telephone, mobile-cellular and fixed-broadband sub-baskets. The IPB is the value calculated from the sum of the price of each sub-basket (in USD) as a percentage of a country’s monthly GNI per capita, divided by three.

variable: Internet and telephony level of competition
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication Regulatory Database
text_source: This variable measures the level of competition in 17 categories of ICT services, including fixed wireless broadband, 3G/4G telephony, international fixed long distance calls and international gateways. For each economy, the level of competition in each of the categories is assessed as follows: monopoly, partial competition and full competition. The results reflect the situation as of 2016 for the majority of countries (for others, data are available as of 2015 or earlier years). The index is calculated as the average of points obtained in each of the 17 categories for which data are available.  A monopoly reflects that the service provided is exclusive to one operator and Scores 0. Partial competition, scoring 1, means that the regulatory framework limits the number of licenses and a full competition, assigned a score of 2, where any company can be licensed to provide the service (categories with no data available are excluded from the computation and the total is allocated to the number of categories in the country).

variable: Laws relating to ICTs
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: How developed are your country’s laws relating to the use of ICTs (e.g., e-commerce, digital signatures, consumer protection)? [1 = not developed at all; 7 = extremely well developed].

variable: Fixed-telephone subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: Fixed-telephone subscriptions refers to the sum of active analogue fixed-telephone lines; voice-over-IP (VoIP) subscriptions; fixed wireless local loop (WLL) subscriptions; ISDN voice-channel equivalents and fixed public payphones. This indicator was previously called 'main telephone lines in operation'; reported per 100 inhabitants.

variable: Mobile-cellular subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: This variable measures the mobile-cellular telephone subscriptions by post-paid/pre-paid per 100 inhabitants. Mobile-cellular telephone subscriptions refers to the number of subscriptions to a public mobile-telephone service that provide access to the PSTN using cellular technology. The indicator includes (and is split into) the number of post-paid subscriptions and the number of active prepaid accounts (i.e. that have been used during the last three months). The indicator applies to all mobile-cellular subscriptions that offer voice communications. It excludes subscriptions via data cards or USB modems; subscriptions to public mobile data services; private trunked mobile radio; telepoint; radio paging and telemetry services.

variable: Fixed-broadband subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: Fixed-broadband subscriptions refers to fixed subscriptions to high-speed access to the public Internet (a TCP/IP connection) at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 Kbit/s. This includes cable modem; DSL; fiber-to-the-home/building; other fixed (wired)-broadband subscriptions; satellite broadband and terrestrial fixed wireless broadband. This total is measured irrespective of the method of payment. It excludes subscriptions that have access to data communications (including the Internet) via mobile-cellular networks. It should include fixed WiMAX and any other fixed wireless technologies. It includes both residential subscriptions and subscriptions for organisations. Computed as fixed broadband subscribers divided by population and multiplied by 100.

variable: Active mobile-broadband subscriptions per 100 inhabitants
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: Active mobile-broadband subscriptions refers to the sum of standard mobile-broadband and dedicated mobile-broadband subscriptions to the public Internet. It covers actual subscribers, not potential subscribers. Even though the latter may have broadband enabled-handsets.

variable: Internet users (%)
text_title: International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database
text_source: This indicator can include both estimates and survey data corresponding to the proportion of individuals using the Internet, based on results from national household surveys. The number should reflect the total population of the country - or at least individuals of 5 years and older. If this number is not available (i.e. target population reflects a more limited age group) an estimate for the entire population should be produced. If this is not possible at this stage, the age group reflected in the number (e.g. population aged 10+; population aged 15-74) should be indicated in a note. If no survey data are available at all, please provide an estimate was provided.

variable: Use of virtual social networks
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how widely are virtual social networks used (e.g., Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn)? [1 = not at all used; 7 = used extensively].

variable: Business-to-consumer Internet use
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do businesses use the Internet for selling their goods and services to consumers? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

variable: Firm-level technology absorption
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do businesses adopt the latest technologies? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

variable: Government Online Service Index
text_title: UN DESA, UN E-Government Knowledgebase
text_source: This index assesses e-government development at the national level, based on data collected from an independent survey questionnaire that assesses the national online presence of all 193 United Nations Member States. The survey questionnaire assesses a number of features related to online service delivery, including whole-of-government approaches, open government data, e-participation, multi-channel service delivery, mobile services, usage up-take, digital divide as well as innovative partnerships through the use of ICT.

variable: Government success in ICT promotion
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how successful is the government in promoting the use of ICTs? [1 = not successful at all; 7 = extremely successful].

variable: Unlicensed software installation rates (%)
text_title: The Software Alliance (BSA), BSA Global Software Survey
text_source: A ratio of the amount of unlicensed software to the total amount of software installed. The amount of unlicensed software is determined by subtracting the quantity of software that was paid for or otherwise legally acquired during the year (such as through an open-source, free or complementary license), segmented by business and consumer usage from the quantity of PC software that was deployed during the year by consumers and business users.

variable: ICT PCT patents, applications/ million population
text_title: World Economic Forum, The Networked Readiness Index Historical Dataset based on WIPO PCT Data sourced from OECD Patent Database and World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Number of applications for information and communications technology – related patents filed under the Patent Cooperation Treaty (PCT) per million population.

variable: Impact of ICTs on business models
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do ICTs enable new business models? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

variable: Social impacts of ICT
text_title: World Economic Forum, The Network Readiness Index Historical Dataset 2012-2016, based on Executive Opinion Survey. 2018 values were recomputed using the same methodology based on updated values from the World Economic Forum Executive Opinion Survey 2018 and the United Nations E-Participation Index 2018
text_source: Social impacts is a pillar under the impact sub index of the Network Readiness Index which assesses a country's social progress brought about or enhanced by the use of ICTs. The pillar focuses on assessing the impact of ICT on access to basic services, education, government efficiency and citizens' engagement in public policymaking through e-government programs. It is composed of four variables, namely: Impact of ICTs on access to basic services, based on a survey question: In your country, to what extent do information and communication technologies (ICTs) enable access for all individuals to basic services (e.g., health, education, financial services, etc.)? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent]. Internet access in schools, based on a survey question: In your country to what extent is the Internet used in schools for learning purposes? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent]. ICT use and government efficiency, based on a survey question: In your country, to what extent does the use of ICTs by the government improve the quality of government services to the population? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent]. E-Participation Index: the E-Participation Index assesses, on a 0-to-1 (best) scale, the quality, relevance and usefulness of government websites in providing online information and participatory tools and services to their citizens.

variable: Ease of starting a business
text_title: World Bank, Doing Business Database
text_source: Measures the paid-in minimum capital requirement, number of procedures, time and cost for a small- to medium-sized limited liability company to start up and formally operate in an economy’s largest business city. These procedures include the processes entrepreneurs undergo when obtaining all necessary approvals, licenses, permits and completing any required notifications, verifications or inscriptions for the company and employees with relevant authorities. The ranking of economies in terms of the ease of starting a business is determined by sorting their distance to frontier scores for starting a business. These scores are the simple average of the distance to frontier scores for each of the component indicators.

variable: Ease of enforcing a contract
text_title: World Bank, Doing Business Database
text_source: Measures the time and cost for resolving a commercial dispute through a local first-instance court, and the quality of judicial processes index, evaluating whether each economy has adopted a series of good practices that promote quality and efficiency in the court system. The data are collected through study of the codes of civil procedure and other court regulations as well as questionnaires completed by local litigation lawyers and judges. The ranking of economies on the ease of enforcing contracts is determined by sorting their distance to frontier scores for enforcing contracts. These scores are the simple average of the distance to frontier scores for each of the component indicators.

variable: Gross fixed capital formation (% of GDP)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Gross fixed capital formation (formerly gross domestic fixed investment) includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation.

variable: Logistics Performance Index
text_title: World Bank/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Logistics Performance Index dataset
text_source: The LPI is an interactive benchmarking tool created to help countries identify the challenges and opportunities they face in trade logistics and what they can do to improve their performance. It is a benchmarking tool developed by the World Bank that measures performance along the logistics supply chain within a country. Allowing for comparisons across 160 countries, the Index can help countries identify challenges and opportunities and improve their logistics performance. The LPI overall score reflects assessments of a country's logistics based on the efficiency of the customs clearance process, quality of trade- and transport-related infrastructure, ease of arranging competitively priced shipments, quality of logistics services, ability to track and trace consignments, and frequency with which shipments reach the consignee within the scheduled time. The Index ranges from 1 to 5, with a higher score representing better performance.

variable: Intensity of local competition
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how intense is competition in the local markets? [1 = not intense at all; 7 = extremely intense].

variable: Availability of latest technologies
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent are the latest technologies available? [1 = not at all; 7 = to a great extent].

variable: Business impact of rules on FDI
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how restrictive are rules and regulations on foreign direct investment (FDI)? [1 = extremely restrictive; 7 = not restrictive at all].

variable: Foreign direct investment, net inflows (% of GDP)
text_title: Index team calculations based on World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Foreign direct investment is the net inflow of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows net inflows (new investment inflows less disinvestment) in the reporting economy from foreign investors, and is divided by GDP. The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: Global Entrepreneurship Index
text_title: Global Entrepreneurship Development Institute, 2018 Global Entrepreneurship Index data
text_source: The Global Entrepreneurship Index is an annual index that measures the health of the entrepreneurship ecosystems in each of 137 countries. It then ranks the performance of these against each other. This provides a picture of how each country performs in both the domestic and international context.

variable: Annual investment in telecommunications services (% of GDP)
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Telecommunication Union (ITU), ITU World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators Database and World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Annual investment in telecom services refers to the investment during the financial year made by entities providing telecommunication networks and/or services (including fixed, mobile and Internet services, as well as the transmission of TV signals) for acquiring or upgrading fixed assets (usually referred to as CAPEX), less disinvestment owing to disposals of fixed assets. Fixed assets should include tangible assets such as buildings and networks, and non-tangible assets such as computer software and intellectual property. The indicator is a measure of investment made by entities providing telecommunication networks and/or services in the country, and includes expenditure on initial installations and additions to existing installations where the usage is expected to be over an extended period of time. It excludes expenditure on fees for operating licenses and the use of radio spectrum, scaled by GDP in current US$. The variable is reported as a three-year average.

variable: Venture capital availability
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how easy is it for start-up entrepreneurs with innovative but risky projects to obtain equity funding? [1 = extremely difficult; 7 = extremely easy].

variable: High-technology net exports (% of total trade)
text_title: Index team calculations based on United Nations Comtrade, International Trade Statistics Database and on IMF, Balance of Payments and International Investment Position Statistics
text_source: High-technology exports minus re-exports expressed as a percentage of total trade. The list of commodities contains technical products with a high intensity of R&D, based on the Eurostat classification, itself based on SITC Rev.4 and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) definition. Commodities belong to the following sectors: aerospace; computers and office machines; electronics, telecommunications; pharmacy; scientific instruments; electrical machinery; chemistry; non- electrical machinery; and armaments. Total trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services excluding trade in government goods and services divided by 2.

variable: Exports of creative services (% of total trade in services)
text_title: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), UN secretarial calculations based on UN DESA Statistics Division, UN Comtrade
text_source: This variable presents exports of creative services by category of service, for individual economies, expressed as percentages of a country's total services trade.

variable: Values and shares of creative goods exports (% of total trade in goods)
text_title: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), UN secretarial calculations based on UN DESA Statistics Division, UN Comtrade
text_source: This variable presents exports of creative goods by individual countries, geographical regions and economic groups, expressed as percentages of a country's total goods trade and broken down by trading partner. The data are also presented as percentage of world (both as economy and trading partner), product totals and region.

variable: Trade (% of GDP)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services measured as a share of gross domestic product.

variable: Prevalence of non-tariff barriers
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, to what extent do non-tariff barriers (e.g., health and product standards, technical and labelling requirements, etc.) limit the ability of imported goods to compete in the domestic market? [1 = strongly limit; 7 = do not limit at all].

variable: Total tax and contribution rate (% of profit)
text_title: World Bank, Doing Business Database
text_source: The total tax rate measures the amount of taxes and mandatory contributions borne by a business in the second year of operation, expressed as a share of commercial profit. Doing Business 2017 reports the total tax rate for calendar year 2015. The total amount of taxes borne is the sum of all the different taxes and contributions payable after accounting for allowable deductions and exemptions. The taxes withheld (such as personal income tax) or collected by the company and remitted to the tax authorities (such as VAT, sales tax or goods and service tax) but not borne by the company are excluded. The taxes included can be divided into five categories: profit or corporate income tax; social contributions and labour taxes paid by the employer (for which all mandatory contributions are included, even if paid to a private entity such as a requited pension fund); property taxes; turnover taxes; and other taxes (such as municipal fees and vehicle taxes). The total tax rate is designed to provide a comprehensive measure of the cost of all the taxes a business bears. It differs from the statutory tax rate, which merely provides the factor to be applied to the tax base. In computing the total tax rate, the actual tax payable is divided by commercial profit. Commercial profit is essentially net profit before all taxes borne. It differs from the conventional profit before tax reported in financial statements. In computing profit before tax, many of the taxes borne by a firm are deductible. In computing commercial profit, these taxes are not deductible. Commercial profit therefore presents a clear picture of the actual profit of a business before any of the taxes it bears in the course of the fiscal year. Commercial profit is computed as sales minus cost of goods sold, minus gross salaries, minus administrative expenses, minus other expenses, minus provisions, plus capital gains (from the sale of property) minus interest expense, plus interest income and minus commercial depreciation.

variable: Soundness of banks
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how do you assess the soundness of banks? [1 = extremely low—banks may require recapitalization; 7 = extremely high—banks are generally healthy with sound balance sheets].

variable: Domestic credit to private sector (% of GDP)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators based on IMF, International Financial Statistics and data files, World Bank and OECD
text_source: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector by financial corporations, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises. Financial corporations include monetary authorities and deposit banks, as well as other financial corporations where data are available (including corporations that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other financial corporations are finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds and foreign exchange companies. Credit to the private sector may sometimes include credit to state-owned or partially state-owned enterprises.

variable: Bank deposits to GDP (%)
text_title: World Bank, Global Financial Development Database
text_source: The total value of demand, time and saving deposits at domestic deposit money banks as a share of GDP. Deposit money banks comprise commercial banks and other financial institutions that accept transferable deposits, such as demand deposits. Demand, time and saving deposits in deposit money banks as a share of GDP is calculated using the following deflation method: {(0.5)*[Ft/P_et + Ft-1/P_et-1]}/[GDPt/P_at] where F is demand and time and saving deposits, P_e is end-of period CPI, and P_a is average annual CPI. Raw data are from the electronic version of the IMF’s International Financial Statistics. Bank deposits (IFS lines 24, 25, FOST and FOSD); GDP in local currency (IFS line NGDP); end-of period CPI (IFS line PCPI); and average annual CPI is calculated using the monthly CPI values (IFS line PCPI).

variable: High-skilled employment share as a percentage of the total number of employed people (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Labour Organisation (ILO), ILOSTAT Database
text_source: Employment comprises all persons of working age who during a specified brief period, such as one week or one day, were in the following categories: a) paid employment (whether at work or with a job but not at work); or b) self-employment (whether at work or with an enterprise but not at work). To favour international comparability, the working-age population is often defined as all persons aged 15 and older, but this may vary from country to country based on national laws and practices.  Information on occupation provides a description of the set of tasks and duties which are carried out by, or can be assigned to, one person. Employed persons are classified by occupations through their relationship to a present job. Skill levels 3 and 4 comprise managers, professionals and technicians and associate professionals based on the International Standard Classification of Occupation (ISCO-08).

variable: Manufacturing, value added (% of GDP)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources.

variable: Political stability and absence of violence/terrorism
text_title: World Bank, Worldwide Governance Indicators
text_source: Political stability and absence of violence/terrorism measures perceptions of the likelihood of political instability and/or politically-motivated violence, including terrorism.

variable: Government effectiveness
text_title: World Bank, Worldwide Governance Indicators
text_source: Government effectiveness reflects perceptions of the quality of public services, the quality of the civil service and the degree of its independence from political pressures, the quality of policy formulation and implementation, and the credibility of the government's commitment to such policies. Estimate of governance (-2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong)).

variable: Judicial independence
text_title: World Economic Forum, Executive Opinion Surveys
text_source: Based on the survey question: In your country, how independent is the judicial system from influences of the government, individuals, or companies? [1 = not independent at all; 7 = entirely independent].

variable: Regulatory quality
text_title: World Bank, Worldwide Governance Indicators
text_source: Regulatory quality reflects perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development.

variable: World Press Freedom Index
text_title: Reporters Without Borders, World Press Freedom Index
text_source: The World Press Freedom Index is an important advocacy tool based on the principle of emulation between states. The Index ranks 180 countries according to the level of freedom available to journalists. It is a snapshot of the media freedom situation based on an evaluation of pluralism, independence of the media, quality of legislative framework and safety of journalists in each country. It does not rank public policies, even if governments obviously have a major impact on their country’s ranking. Nor is it an indicator of the quality of journalism in each country. Countries have been given scores ranging from 0 to 100, with 0 being the best possible score and 100 the worst.

variable: Women-to-men ratio in parliament (%)
text_title: Index team calculations based on Inter-Parliamentary Union, PARLINE Database
text_source: It is the percentage of women in parliament divided by the percentage of men in parliament. The percentage of women in parliament is based on the number of seats held by women members in single or lower chambers of national parliaments, expressed as a percentage of all occupied seats. It is derived by dividing the total number of seats occupied by women by the total number of seats in parliament. The percentage of men in parliament is derived by subtracting the percentage of women in parliament from 100.

variable: Educational attainment: at least completed upper secondary (ISCED 3 or higher), population 25+ years, gender parity index (GPI)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Gender parity index (GPI) is the ratio of female to male values of a given variable. Educational attainment is the highest ISCED level of education an individual has successfully completed. This is usually measured with respect to the highest educational programme successfully completed, which is typically certified by a recognized qualification. Recognized intermediate qualifications are classified at a lower level than the programme itself.

variable: Labour force participation rate, female-to-male ratio (15+)
text_title: Index team calculations based on International Labour Organisation (ILO), ILOSTAT Database
text_source: This is the ratio of female labour force participation to that of males. The labour force participation rate is a measure of the proportion of a country’s working-age population that engages actively in the labour market, either by working or looking for work; it provides an indication of the size of the supply of labour available to engage in the production of goods and services, relative to the working age population.  The labour force comprises all persons of working age who furnish the supply of labour for the production of goods and services during a specified time-reference period. It refers to the sum of all persons of working age who are employed and those who are unemployed.

variable: Adult literacy rate, population 15+ years, both sexes (%)
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database
text_source: Percentage of population aged 15 years and over who can both read and write – with understanding – a short simple statement on his/her everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. Adult illiteracy is defined as the percentage of the population aged 15 years and over who cannot both read and write – with understanding – a short simple statement on his/her everyday life.

variable: Mean years of schooling (ISCED 1 or higher), population 25+ years, both sexes
text_title: UNESCO Institute for Statistics, UIS Database and Barro-Lee, Educational Attainment Dataset
text_source: Average number of completed years of education of a country's population aged 25 years and older, excluding years spent repeating individual grades.

variable: GDP per capita, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators
text_source: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using Purchasing Power Parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the US dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.

variable: Unemployment rate, 15+ (%)
text_title: International Labour Organisation (ILO), ILOSTAT Database
text_source: The unemployment rate is calculated by expressing the number of unemployed persons as a percentage of the total number of persons in the labour force. The labour force (formerly known as the economically active population) is the sum of the number of persons employed and the number of persons unemployed.

variable: Share of youth not in employment, education or training (NEET) (%)
text_title: International Labour Organisation (ILO), ILOSTAT Database
text_source: The share of youth not in education, employment or training (also known as the NEET rate") conveys the number of young persons not in education
text_body: employment or training as a percentage of the total youth population. It provides a measure of youth who are outside the educational system
column6: not in training and not in employment
column7: and thus serves as a broader measure of potential youth labour market entrants than youth unemployment
column8: since it also includes young persons outside the labour force not in education or training."

variable: Under-five mortality rate (probability of dying by age of 5 per 1000 live births)
text_title: World Health Organization (WHO), Global Health Observatory and UN DESA, World Population Prospects 2019
text_source: Probability (expressed as a rate per 1,000 live births) of a child born in a specific year or period dying before reaching the age of five years, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of that period. Numerator: deaths at age 0–5 years. Denominator: number of surviving children at beginning of specified age range during the 10 years prior to the survey.

variable: Life expectancy at birth, both sexes (years)
text_title: World Health Organization (WHO), Global Health Observatory and UN DESA, World Population Prospects 2019
text_source: Average number of years that a new-born is expected to live if current mortality rates apply. Life expectancy at birth reflects the overall mortality level of a population. It summarizes the mortality pattern that prevails across all age groups: children and adolescents, adults and the elderly.

variable: Total CO2 emissions excluding land-use change and forestry per capita (tCO2 per capita)
text_title: International Energy Agency (IEA), World Energy Balances 2019
text_source: For newly formed countries, the share of carbon emissions for the years prior to country formation is estimated based on each country’s carbon emissions in the five years immediately following its formation (or the first five years for which data are available). Per capita: shows the value per person for the countries/states/regions selected, based on the population data found within CAIT.

variable: Energy intensity level of primary energy (MJ/2011 USD PPP)
text_title: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from the SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework led jointly by the World Bank, International Energy Agency, and the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program
text_source: A ratio between energy supply and gross domestic product measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output.

variable: Renewable energy consumption (% of total final energy consumption)
text_title: World Bank, World Development Indicators from Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from the SE4ALL Global Tracking Framework led jointly by the World Bank, International Energy Agency, and the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program
text_source: Renewable energy consumption is the share of renewable energy in total final energy consumption. Renewable energy consumption includes consumption of energy derived from: hydro, solid biofuels, wind, solar, liquid biofuels, biogas, geothermal, marine and waste.
